methods.value: one or more filenames to include as if the Javascript code was written in place. This is similar to a C #include function.

methods.name: removeEventListener
methods.value: remove a previously added event listener

Titanium.notes:
Titanium provides a number of built-in objects in the Javascript that are not part of the Titanium namespace. Specifically, the following are available.

JSON

Titanium has a built-in JSON parser with two main functions: parse and stringify. JSON.parse will safely evaluate a string encoded as Javascript into a Javascript object. JSON.stringify will encode a Javascript object into a string.

Timers

Titanium has built-in support for one-shot and repeating timers with two main functions: setTimeout and setInterval. setTimeout takes 2 arguments: function and timeout in milliseconds after which the function should be executed and returns a timer handle that can be used to cancel a pending timer with clearTimeout. setInterval takes 2 arguments: function and timeout in milliseconds for how often the function should be executed until cancelled and returns a timer handle that can be used to cancel a timer with clearInterval.

Alert

Titanium has a built-in convenience function alert which can be used as a shortcut to Titanium.UI.createAlertDialog for creating a message box. Note that unlike a web browser-based version of alert, the method is asynchronous.

Titanium.Accelerometer.description: The top level Accelerometer module. The Accelerometer modules contains methods and properties for using the device accelerometer.

events.name: update

properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.timestamp: reference timestamp since the previous change. this is not a valid timestamp and should simply be used to determine the time between events and not an exact timestamp.
properties.type: the name of the event fired
properties.x: the x axis of the device
properties.y: the y axis of the device

events.value: fired when the accelerometer changes

examples.code:
Adds an accelerometer update event listener which prints out the x, y and z axis as the device is moved. You should generally remove the event when not used to conserve device resources. If you do not have an active event listener, the accelerometer is turned off to conserve device resources.

Titanium.Accelerometer.addEventListener('update',function(e)
{
    Ti.API.debug("accelerometer - x:"+e.x+",y:"+e.y+",z:"+e.z);
});

Titanium.Accelerometer.notes:
You'll want to be selective about turning on and off the device accelerometer. It's recommended you turn off the accelerometer when you're not using it.

You can turn off the accelerometer by simply removing your event listener function. You can turn it back on by re-adding the same function with addEventListener.

Titanium.Accelerometer.removeEventListener('update',myFunction);

Titanium.Analytics.description: The top level Analytics module. The Analytics module is used for transmitting developer-defined Analytics event for your application to the Appcelerator Analytics product. It can be used to augment additional context or application-specific information which can then be accessed during analysis using Analytics.

examples.code:
This examples shows how to send a featureEvent during an application session to indicate some feature was triggered/used by the user that you would like to track.

Titanium.Analytics.featureEvent('app.feature.blah',{product:'killer'});

Titanium.Contacts.Person.description: An object which represents a person in the contacts database.
Titanium.Contacts.Person.notes: There are two kinds of properties: single value and multivalue. Single value properties are returned as a direct value, while mutlivalue properties are returned as dictionary objects with keys which represent labels of the property, with values that are arrays of all values in the property which correspond to that label (e.g. {"home" : [address1, address2]})

properties.name: URL
properties.value: URLs of webpages associated with the person. Multi-value, valid labels are: home, work, other, homepage. Values are strings.

properties.name: address
properties.value: The addresses for the person. Multi-value, valid labels are: home, work, other. Values are dictionaries.

properties.name: birthday
properties.value: The birthday of the person. Single value, format is "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss'.'SSS+0000"

properties.name: created
properties.value: The date the person was created in the database. Single value, format is "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss'.'SSS+0000", read-only

properties.name: date
properties.value: Dates associated with the person. Multi-value, valid labels are: anniversary. Values are strings of format "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss'.'SSS+0000"

properties.name: department
properties.value: The department of the person. Single value

properties.name: email
properties.value: The email addresses for the person. Multi-value, valid labels are: home, work, other. Values are strings.

properties.name: firstName
properties.value: The first name of the person. Single value

properties.name: firstPhonetic
properties.value: The phonetic first name of the person. Single value

properties.name: fullName
properties.value: The localized full name of the person. Single value, read-only

properties.name: image
properties.value: A blob object representing the image for the person. Set to null to remove the image. Single value

properties.name: instantMessage
properties.value: The instant messenger names for the person. Multi-value, valid labels are: aim, icq, jabber, msn, yahoo. Values are dictionaries.

properties.name: jobTitle
properties.value: The job title of the person. Single value

properties.name: kind
properties.value: The kind of person. Single value, one of Titanium.Contacts.CONTACTS_KIND_PERSON or Titanium.Contacts.CONTACTS_KIND_ORGANIZATION

properties.name: lastName
properties.value: The last name of the person. Single value

properties.name: lastPhonetic
properties.value: The phonetic last name of the person. Single value

properties.name: middleName
properties.value: The middle name of the person. Single value

properties.name: middlePhonetic
properties.value: The phonetic middle name of the person. Single value

properties.name: modified
properties.value: The most recent date the person was modified. Single value, format is "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss'.'SSS+0000", read-only

properties.name: nickname
properties.value: The nickname of the person. Single value

properties.name: note
properties.value: Notes for the person. Single value

properties.name: organization
properties.value: The organization the person belongs to. Single value

properties.name: phone
properties.value: The phone numbers for the person. Multi-value, valid labels are: home, work, other, mobile, pager, workFax, homeFax, main, iPhone. Values are strings.

properties.name: prefix
properties.value: The prefix for the person. Single value

properties.name: relatedNames
properties.value: The names of people the person is related to. Multi-value, valid labels are: mother, father, parent, sister, brother, child, friend, spouse, partner, manager, assistant. Values are strings.

properties.name: suffix
properties.value: The suffix for the person. Single value

properties.value: the background color of the view

properties.value: a background gradient for the view with the properties: type,startPoint,endPoint,startRadius,endRadius,backfillStart,backfillEnd,colors.

properties.name: backgroundImage
properties.value: the background image url of the view

properties.name: backgroundLeftCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the left end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The right end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the left end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the width of the image

properties.name: backgroundTopCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the top end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The bottom end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the top end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the height of the image

Titanium.Map.description: The top level Map module. The Map module is used for creating in-application native maps.

examples.code:
This is a basic map example that uses a custom annotation on the map.

var mountainView = Titanium.Map.createAnnotation({
    latitude:37.390749,
    longitude:-122.081651,
    title:"Appcelerator Headquarters",
    subtitle:'Mountain View, CA',
    pincolor:Titanium.Map.ANNOTATION_RED,
    animate:true,
    leftButton: '../images/appcelerator_small.png',
    myid:1 // CUSTOM ATTRIBUTE THAT IS PASSED INTO EVENT OBJECTS
});

var mapview = Titanium.Map.createView({
    mapType: Titanium.Map.STANDARD_TYPE,
    region: {latitude:33.74511, longitude:-84.38993, 
            latitudeDelta:0.01, longitudeDelta:0.01},
    animate:true,
    regionFit:true,
    userLocation:true,
    annotations:[mountainView]
});

win.add(mapview);

properties.name: backgroundLeftCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the left end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The right end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the left end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the width of the image

This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the top end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The bottom end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the top end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the height of the image

properties.value: property for the view right position. this position is relative to the views parent. can be either a float value or a string of the width.

properties.name: size
properties.value: the size of the view as a dictionary of width and height properties

properties.name: top
properties.value: property for the view top position. this position is relative to the views parent. can be either a float value or a string of the width.

properties.name: touchEnabled
properties.value: a boolean indicating if the view should receive touch events (true, default) or forward them to peers (false)

properties.name: transform
properties.value: the transformation matrix to apply to the view

properties.name: userLocation
properties.value: boolean to indicate if the map should show the user's current device location as a pin on the map

properties.name: visible
properties.value: a boolean of the visibility of the view

properties.name: width
properties.value: property for the view width. can either be `auto`, a float value or a string of the width.

properties.name: zIndex
properties.value: the z index position relative to other sibling views

methods.value: hide the device camera UI. this must be called after calling showCamera and only when autohide is set to false. this method will cause the media capture device be hidden.

methods.value: hide the music library. This must be called after calling showMusicLibrary and only when autohide is set to false. iPhone and iPad only.

parameters.description: media type as a string of either <tt>camera</tt>, <tt>photo</tt> or <tt>photogallery</tt>.

parameters.description: the type of media to check
parameters.name: type

methods.value: return boolean to indicate if the media type is supported

methods.name: openPhotoGallery

parameters.description: pass a dictionary with the following supported keys: <tt>success</tt> a function that will be called when the camera is completed, <tt>error</tt> a function that will be called upon receiving an error, <tt>cancel</tt> a function that will be called if the user presses the cancel button, <tt>autohide</tt> boolean if the camera should auto hide after the media capture is completed (defaults to true), <tt>animated</tt> boolean if the dialog should be animated (defaults to true) upon showing and hiding, <tt>saveToPhotoGallery</tt> boolean if the media should be saved to the photo gallery upon successful capture, <tt>allowEditing</tt> boolean if the media should be editable after capture in the UI interface, <tt>mediaTypes</tt> an array of media type constants supported by the capture device UI, <tt>showControls</tt> boolean to indicate if the built-in UI controls should be displayed, <tt>overlay</tt> view which is added as an overlay to the UI (on top), <tt>transform</tt> an transformation matrix that applies to the UI transform. For iPad, <tt>popoverView</tt> can be provided to position the photo gallery popover a specific view and <tt>arrowDirection</tt> can be provided to control the type of arrow and position of the gallery.
parameters.name: options

methods.value: open the photo gallery picker

methods.name: removeEventListener
methods.value: remove a previously added event listener

methods.name: saveToPhotoGallery

parameters.description: save the media passed to the cameras photo roll/media gallery. must be one of Blob object or File object or an error will be generated.
parameters.name: media

methods.value: save media to photo gallery / camera roll

methods.name: showCamera

parameters.description: pass a dictionary with the following supported keys: <tt>success</tt> a function that will be called when the camera is completed, <tt>error</tt> a function that will be called upon receiving an error, <tt>cancel</tt> a function that will be called if the user presses the cancel button, <tt>autohide</tt> boolean if the camera should auto hide after the media capture is completed (defaults to true), <tt>animated</tt> boolean if the dialog should be animated (defaults to true) upon showing and hiding, <tt>saveToPhotoGallery</tt> boolean if the media should be saved to the photo gallery upon successful capture, <tt>allowEditing</tt> boolean if the media should be editable after capture in the UI interface, <tt>mediaTypes</tt> an array of media type constants supported by the capture device UI, <tt>videoMaximumDuration</tt> float duration on how long in milliseconds to allow capture before completing, <tt>videoQuality</tt> constant to indicate the video quality during capture, <tt>showControls</tt> boolean to indicate if the built-in UI controls should be displayed, <tt>overlay</tt> view which is added as an overlay to the camera UI (on top), <tt>transform</tt> an transformation matrix that applies to the camera UI transform.
parameters.name: options

methods.value: show the camera

methods.name: showMusicLibrary

parameters.description: pass a dictionary with the following supported keys: <tt>success</tt> a function that will be called when the camera is completed, <tt>error</tt> a function that will be called upon receiving an error, <tt>cancel</tt> a function that will be called if the user presses the cancel button, <tt>autohide</tt> boolean if the library listing should auto hide after selection is completed (defaults to true), <tt>animated</tt> boolean if the dialog should be animated (defaults to true) upon showing and hiding, <tt>mediaTypes</tt> an array of media type constants defining selectable media (see MUSIC_MEDIA_TYPE_* properties below) as either an array or a bitwise-or single value, <tt>allowMultipleSelections</tt> boolean whether or not more than one media selection is allowed
parameters.name: options

methods.value: show the music library. iPhone and iPad only.

properties.name: AUDIO_SESSION_MODE_AMBIENT
properties.value: For long-duration sounds such as rain, car engine noise, and so on. It is also for 'play along' style applications, such a virtual piano that a user plays over iPod audio.

properties.name: AUDIO_SESSION_MODE_PLAYBACK
properties.value: For playing recorded music or other sounds that are central to the successful use of your application. When using this mode, your application audio continues with the Ring/Silent switch set to silent or when the screen locks. This property normally disallows iPod audio to mix with application audio

properties.name: AUDIO_SESSION_MODE_PLAY_AND_RECORD
properties.value: Allows recording (input) and playback (output) of audio, such as for a VOIP (voice over IP) application. This category is appropriate for simultaneous recording and playback, and also for applications that record and play back but not simultaneously. If you want to ensure that sounds such as Messages alerts do not play while your application is recording, use Titanium.Media.AUDIO_SESSION_MODE_RECORD instead. This category normally disallows iPod audio to mix with application audio.

properties.name: AUDIO_SESSION_MODE_RECORD
properties.value: For recording audio; it silences playback audio.

properties.name: AUDIO_SESSION_MODE_SOLO_AMBIENT
properties.value: The solo ambient sound category is for long-duration sounds such as rain, car engine noise, and so on. When you use this category, audio from built-in applications, such as the iPod, is silenced. Your audio is silenced when the Ring/Silent switch is set to silent or when the screen locks.

properties.name: VIDEO_PLAYBACK_STATE_STOPPED

properties.name: VIDEO_REPEAT_MODE_ONE
properties.value: the video will repeat once

properties.name: VIDEO_SCALING_ASPECT_FILL
properties.value: constant for video aspect where the movie will be scaled until the movie fills the entire screen. Content at the edges of the larger of the two dimensions is clipped so that the other dimension fits the screen exactly. The aspect ratio of the movie is preserved.

properties.name: VIDEO_SCALING_ASPECT_FIT
properties.value: constant for video aspect fit where the movie will be scaled until one dimension fits on the screen exactly. In the other dimension, the region between the edge of the movie and the edge of the screen is filled with a black bar. The aspect ratio of the movie is preserved.

properties.name: VIDEO_SCALING_MODE_FILL
properties.value: constant for video aspect where the movie will be scaled until both dimensions fit the screen exactly. The aspect ratio of the movie is not preserved.

properties.name: VIDEO_SCALING_NONE
properties.value: constant for video scaling where the scaling is turn off. The movie will not be scaled.

properties.name: VIDEO_SOURCE_TYPE_FILE
properties.value: the video source type is a file. Related to the sourceType property of Titanium.Media.VideoPlayer

properties.name: VIDEO_SOURCE_TYPE_STREAMING
properties.value: the video source type is a remote stream. Related to the sourceType property of Titanium.Media.VideoPlayer

properties.name: VIDEO_SOURCE_TYPE_UNKNOWN
properties.value: the video source type is unknown. Related to the sourceType property of Titanium.Media.VideoPlayer

properties.name: VIDEO_TIME_OPTION_EXACT
properties.value: use the exact time

properties.name: VIDEO_TIME_OPTION_NEAREST_KEYFRAME
properties.value: use the closest keyframe in the time

Titanium.Media.Sound.description: The Sound object is returned by Titanium.Media.createSound and is useful for playing basic sounds. The Sound object loads the entire media resource in memory before playing. If you need to support streaming, use the Titanium.Media.createAudioPlayer API.

player.play();

Prior to 3.2, only fullscreen views were available on iPhone.

properties.name: backgroundLeftCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the left end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The right end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the left end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the width of the image

properties.name: backgroundTopCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the top end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The bottom end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the top end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the height of the image

Titanium.Network.BonjourBrowser.description: The BonjourBrowser instance returned from Titanium.Network.createBonjourBrowser. This object is a browser for the discovery and retrieval of Bonjour services available on the network.

properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: An array of BonjourService objects corresponding to currently available services. If you cache this value, including using it as table data, be aware that it could become out of date at any time due to the asynchronous nature of Bonjour service discovery.

properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: Fired when the discovered services list is updated

methods.name: search
methods.value: Conduct a search for Bonjour services matching the type and domain specified during creation

methods.name: stopSearch
methods.value: Halt an ongoing search

Titanium.Network.BonjourBrowser.notes: If your application publishes Bonjour services itself, that service will be discovered by the browser if necessary; be prepared to perform a check if you do not want to list local services as available. Bonjour service browsing is an asynchronous operation, meaning that you should be extremely careful when caching values from the 'services' property returned by the updatedServices event. In particular, if you maintain a local copy of available services and a user tries to connect to one, you should be prepared to handle failures gracefully; the next updatedServices event should provide the new services list, but you should not rely on it being delivered before user input. When a window which uses Bonjour browsing is closed, if you do not want to continue searching, you must call the stop() method.

properties.name: domain
properties.value: The domain the browser is searching in

properties.name: isSearching
properties.value: Whether or not the browser is currently searching

properties.name: serviceType
properties.value: The type of the service the browser searches for

Titanium.Network.BonjourService.description: The BonjourService instance returned either from Titanium.Network.createBonjourService or via the service list from a BonjourBrowser updatedServices event. This object describes a service on the network which is published by Bonjour.

methods.name: publish

parameters.description: a TCPSocket object to associate with the Bonjour service.
parameters.name: socket

methods.value: Publish a Bonjour service to the network. Only works if isLocal is TRUE

methods.name: resolve

parameters.description: the timeout for service resolution, in seconds.  Optional, default is 120s.
parameters.name: timeout

methods.value: Resolve a Bonjour service from the network. Must be done before attempting to access the service's socket information, if a remote service. You cannot resolve a locally published service.

methods.name: stop
methods.value: Halts publication of a service.

Titanium.Network.BonjourService.notes: You can only publish Bonjour services attached to a socket which is currently listening; you cannot publish a service for a remotely connected socket. If you stop the Bonjour service and wish to close the socket it uses, it is strongly recommended that you stop the service first. When a window which publishes a Bonjour service is closed, you must stop the service if the associated socket is also to be closed, or if it is no longer necessary to publish. Unlike other network operations, Bonjour service resolution and publishing is synchronous, so be aware that your code may block while resolution is going on. In particular, you may wish to display UI elements indicating background activity before beginning resolution.

Titanium.Network.TCPSocket.notes: Sockets are nontrivial; it is recommended that anyone using them be familiar with the basics of BSD sockets. All sockets use TCP connections, and are asynchronous for read operations, so your program should be ready to receive 'read' events at any point. Socket references cannot be transferred to socket objects, and vice-versa - socket references are an internal mechanism which is used only to determine which sockets to send data to and read data from. For listening sockets, it is highly recommended that you use the Titanium.Network.INADDR_ANY constant as the host name. If a window containing a socket is closed, the socket MUST be closed also unless you intend to continue to receive data, otherwise the socket will consume resources (and potentially cause conflicts with opening the window again, if a listener) until the program is restarted. Be aware of the differences between the listen() and connect() functions; attempting to use one when you mean the other may result in errors, unpredictable behavior, or both.

Titanium.UI.notes:
Design

The UI module is broken down into 3 major area:

  • Views - Views are containers that host visual elements such as controls or other views. Views can have their properties customized, such as their border color and radius, can fire events such as swipe events or touches, and can optionally contain a hierarchy or other views as children. In Titanium, most views are specialized to perform both a visual function and set of interaction behaviors such as Table View or Coverflow View. Views are always named with the suffix View.
  • Controls - controls, or sometimes referred as widgets, are visual elements such as sliders, buttons and switches. They provide a visual element which has a defined behavior and typical have special configuration and special events. Controls themselves are views and also inherit a views properties, functions and events.
  • Windows - Windows are typically top-level visual constructs that are the main part of your interface. An application will always have at least one window and windows can take different shapes and sizes, can have display and interaction properties such as fullscreen or modal and can be customized, such as changing their opacity or background color. Windows themselves are views and also inherit a views properties, functions and events. There are a few specialization of Windows such as a Tab Group which offer additional behavior beyond the basic Window.

Titanium uses the Factory Pattern for constructing objects and a general naming pattern for APIs. For example, to construct a Alert Dialog, you call the method Titanium.UI.createAlertDialog. To create a TextArea, you call the method Titanium.UI.createTextArea. Once an object is created, it will be available until it goes out of scope.

Optimizations

UI objects are optimized by Titanium to not be realized into the drawing context and placed into the device UI surface until needed. That means that you can create UI objects, set their properties and add them to their hierarchy without much worry about memory or performance. When the native drawing surface needs to render a specific view or control, Titanium will automatically create the view as needed. Additionally, Titanium is optimized to also release memory once the view is no longer needed, on screen or in low memory situations. However, it's a good idea to help Titanium along in certain cases where you are no longer using objects. For example, you should call close on a Window instance when you are no longer using it. You can safely call open on the Window again to re-open it.

Global Context and Threading

Be careful with the objects that are created in app.js but only used once. Since the app.js context is global and generally is not garbage collected until the application exits, you should think about the design of your application as it relates to this fact. Window objects that are opened up with the url property to another Javascript file contain a nice way to decompose your application into smaller units. The other benefit is that when a Window is closed, its resources can be immediately cleaned up, saving resources such as memory and CPU. Additionally, Window objects run in a separate Javascript context and Thread. While all UI processing is done on the main UI thread, other processing inside a Window or the app.js that does not have UI interaction will run in its own thread.

Portability

Titanium components are designed to be portable across as many platforms as it supports. However, there are cases where a device either does not support a specific feature or capability or where it support additional functionality. For cases where the device OS supports capabilities that other platforms do not, we attempt to place those capabilities in a separate namespace, such as Titanium.UI.iPhone. However, in cases where the control is in a common namespace and support additional features, we continue to place that functionality directly on the object.

Titanium.UI.2DMatrix.description: The 2DMatrix is created by Titanium.UI.create2DMatrix. The 2D Matrix is an object for holding values for an affine transformation matrix. A 2D matrix is used to rotate, scale, translate, or skew the objects in a two-dimensional space. A 2D matrix is represented by a 3 by 3 matrix. Because the third column is always (0,0,1), the data structure contains values for only the first two columns.

methods.value: Returns a matrix constructed by inverting an existing matrix

methods.name: multiply

parameters.description: The second matrix. This matrix is concatenated to the matrix instance against which the function is invoked.  The result of this function is the first matrix multiplied by the second matrix. You might perform several multiplications in order to create a single matrix that contains the cumulative effects of several transformations. Note that matrix operations are not commutative - the order in which you concatenate matrices is important. That is, the result of multiplying matrix t1 by matrix t2 does not necessarily equal the result of multiplying matrix t2 by matrix t1.
parameters.name: t2

methods.value: Returns a matrix constructed by combining two existing matrix.

Titanium.UI.3DMatrix.description: The 2DMatrix is created by Titanium.UI.create2DMatrix. The 2D Matrix is an object for holding values for an affine transformation matrix. A 2D matrix is used to rotate, scale, translate, or skew the objects in a three-dimensional space. A 3D matrix is represented by a 4 by 4 matrix. Because the forth column is always (0,0,1), the data structure contains values for only the first three columns.

methods.name: multiply

parameters.description: The second matrix. This matrix is concatenated to the matrix instance against which the function is invoked.  The result of this function is the first matrix multiplied by the second matrix. You might perform several multiplications in order to create a single matrix that contains the cumulative effects of several transformations. Note that matrix operations are not commutative - the order in which you concatenate matrices is important. That is, the result of multiplying matrix t1 by matrix t2 does not necessarily equal the result of multiplying matrix t2 by matrix t1.

Titanium.UI.ActivityIndicator.description: An Activity Indicator is created by the method Titanium.UI.createActivityIndicator. An activity indicator can be used to show the progress of an operation in the UI to let the user know some action is taking place.

examples.code:
In this example, we create a basic activity indicator and start it.

var actInd = Titanium.UI.createActivityIndicator({
    height:50,
    width:10
});
actInd.show();

methods.name: hide
methods.value: call hide to make the activity indicator hidden and stop spinning

methods.name: show
methods.value: call show to make the activity indicator visible and start spinning

Titanium.UI.AlertDialog.description: The Alert Dialog is created by Titanium.UI.createAlertDialog and allows you to show a modal application dialog.

examples.code:
In this example, we show a simple alert dialog.

var alertDialog = Titanium.UI.createAlertDialog({

});
alertDialog.show();

Titanium.UI.AlertDialog.notes:
the global method alert is aliased to this object and can be invoked with a single message. For example:

alert("this is a message");

Note: you should be careful not to call alert more than once while a pending alert is visible.

On iOS 4, alert dialogs will automatically be cancelled upon application suspend.

Titanium.UI.Android.OptionMenu.description: The menu that appears at the lower portion of the display when the device's Menu button is pressed.

examples.code:
var menu = Titanium.UI.Android.OptionMenu.createMenu();

var item1 = Titanium.UI.Android.OptionMenu.createMenuItem({
    title : 'Item 1',
    icon : '/images/item1.png'
});

item1.addEventListener('click', function(){
    Ti.UI.createAlertDialog({ title : 'You clicked Item 1'}).show();
});

var item2 = Titanium.UI.Android.OptionMenu.createMenuItem({
    title : 'Refresh',
    icon : '/images/refresh.png'
});
item2.addEventListener('click', function(){
    Ti.UI.createAlertDialog({ title : 'You clicked Refresh'}).show();
});

menu.add(item1);
menu.add(item2);

// Set the menu on the current heavyweight window. A heavyweight window maps to an Android
// Activity. To create a heavyweight window, specify one or more of [**fullscreen**,**navBarHidden**,**modal**] to createWindow.

Titanium.UI.Android.OptionMenu.setMenu(menu);

Titanium.UI.Animation.description: The Animation object is used for specifying lower-level animation properties and more low-level control of events during an animation. The Animation is created by the method Titanium.UI.createAnimation.

events.name: complete

properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: fired when the animation completes

events.name: start

properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: fired when the animation starts

examples.code:
Create a simple animation and apply it to the view. In this example, the view will animate from red to black to orange over 2 seconds.

var view = Titanium.UI.createView({
   backgroundColor:'red'
});
var animation = Titanium.UI.createAnimation();
animation.backgroundColor = 'black';
animation.duration = 1000;
animation.addEventListener('complete',function()
{
   animation.removeEventListener('complete',this);
   animation.backgroundColor = 'orange';
   view.animate(animation);
});
view.animate(animation);

properties.value: url to a button image that is drawn as the background of the button

properties.name: backgroundLeftCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the left end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The right end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the left end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the width of the image

properties.name: backgroundSelectedImage
properties.value: url to a button image that is drawn as the background of the button when the button is in the selected state

properties.name: backgroundTopCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the top end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The bottom end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the top end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the height of the image

properties.name: anchorPoint
properties.value: a dictionary with properties x and y to indicate the anchor point value. anchor specifies the position by which animation should occur. center is 0.5, 0.5

properties.name: animatedCenterPoint
properties.value: read-only object with x and y properties of where the view is during animation

properties.name: backgroundColor
properties.value: the background color of the button bar

properties.name: backgroundGradient
properties.value: a background gradient for the view with the properties: type,startPoint,endPoint,startRadius,endRadius,backfillStart,backfillEnd,colors.

properties.name: backgroundImage
properties.value: the background image url of the view

properties.name: backgroundLeftCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the left end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The right end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the left end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the width of the image

properties.name: backgroundTopCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the top end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The bottom end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the top end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the height of the image

Titanium.UI.EmailDialog.description: The Email Dialog is created by Titanium.UI.createEmailDialog and allows you to send in application emails on behalf of the application user.

events.name: complete

properties.error: string message of the error or null if successfully sent
properties.result: result status either as SENT, SAVED, CANCELLED or FAILED. (Note: Android result will be SENT even if user discards or saves the message. SAVED and CANCELLED are not supported on Android.)
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.success: boolean to indicate if the email was successfully sent
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: fired when the email dialog has completed sending the email

examples.code:
In this example, we send an email with a file attachment.

var emailDialog = Titanium.UI.createEmailDialog()
emailDialog.subject = "Hello from Titanium";
emailDialog.toRecipients = ['foo@yahoo.com'];
emailDialog.messageBody = 'Appcelerator Titanium Rocks!';
var f = Ti.Filesystem.getFile('cricket.wav');
emailDialog.addAttachment(f);
emailDialog.open();

methods.name: addAttachment

parameters.description: attachment object as either a Blob or File object
parameters.name: attachment

methods.value: add an attachment to the email. the attachment can either be a Blob or File object. (Note: Android will only accept one attachment at this time.)

methods.name: addEventListener

parameters.description: callback function to invoke when the event is fired
parameters.name: callback

methods.value: add an event listener for the instance to receive view triggered events

methods.name: fireEvent
methods.value: fire a synthesized event to the views listener

methods.name: open

parameters.description: object of animation properties. pass <tt>animated</tt> property (as boolean) to indicate if the dialog should be animated on open.
parameters.name: properties

methods.value: open the email dialog. the email dialog itself is a modal window

methods.name: removeEventListener
methods.value: remove a previously added event listener

properties.name: CANCELLED
properties.value: constant for the CANCELLED status result

properties.name: FAILED
properties.value: constant for the FAILED status result

Titanium.UI.ImageView.description: An Image View is used to display an image or a series of images in an animation. The Image View is created by the method Titanium.UI.createImageView.

events.name: change

properties.index: the index of the image frame being displayed
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: fired for each frame changed during an animation

events.name: click

properties.globalPoint: a dictionary with properties x and y describing the point of the event in screen coordinates
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired
properties.x: the x point of the event in receiving view coordiantes
properties.y: the y point of the event, in receiving view coordinates

events.value: fired when the device detects a click (longer than touch) against the view

events.name: dblclick

properties.globalPoint: a dictionary with properties x and y describing the point of the event in screen coordinates
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired
properties.x: the x point of the event in receiving view coordiantes
properties.y: the y point of the event, in receiving view coordinates

events.value: fired when the device detects a double click against the view

events.name: doubletap

properties.globalPoint: a dictionary with properties x and y describing the point of the event in screen coordinates
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired
properties.x: the x point of the event in receiving view coordiantes
properties.y: the y point of the event, in receiving view coordinates

events.value: fired when the device detects a double tap against the view

events.name: load

properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.state: either url to indicate the url property is loaded or images when all the images are loaded
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: fired when either the initial image and/or all of the images in an animation are loaded

events.name: singletap

properties.globalPoint: a dictionary with properties x and y describing the point of the event in screen coordinates
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired
properties.x: the x point of the event in receiving view coordiantes
properties.y: the y point of the event, in receiving view coordinates

events.value: fired when the device detects a single tap against the view

events.name: start

properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: fired when the animation starts

events.name: stop

properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: fired when the animation stops

events.name: swipe

properties.direction: direction of the swipe - either left or right
properties.globalPoint: a dictionary with properties x and y describing the point of the event in screen coordinates
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired
properties.x: the x point of the event in receiving view coordiantes
properties.y: the y point of the event, in receiving view coordinates

events.value: fired when the device detects a swipe (left or right) against the view

events.name: touchcancel

properties.globalPoint: a dictionary with properties x and y describing the point of the event in screen coordinates
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired
properties.x: the x point of the event in receiving view coordiantes
properties.y: the y point of the event, in receiving view coordinates

events.value: fired when a touch event is interrupted by the device. this happens in circumenstances such as an incoming call to allow the UI to clean up state.

events.name: touchend

properties.globalPoint: a dictionary with properties x and y describing the point of the event in screen coordinates
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired
properties.x: the x point of the event in receiving view coordiantes
properties.y: the y point of the event, in receiving view coordinates

events.value: fired when a touch event is completed

events.name: touchmove

properties.globalPoint: a dictionary with properties x and y describing the point of the event in screen coordinates
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired
properties.x: the x point of the event in receiving view coordiantes
properties.y: the y point of the event, in receiving view coordinates

events.value: fired as soon as the device detects movement of a touch.  Event coordinates are always relative to the view in which the initial touch occurred

properties.globalPoint: a dictionary with properties x and y describing the point of the event in screen coordinates

properties.y: the y point of the event, in receiving view coordinates

properties.y: the y point of the event, in receiving view coordinates

examples.code:
In this example, we create a simple image view:

var image = Titanium.UI.createImageView({url:'myimage.png'});
view.add(image);

methods.name: add

parameters.description: the view to add to this views hiearchy
parameters.name: view

methods.value: add a child to the view hierarchy

methods.name: addEventListener

parameters.description: callback function to invoke when the event is fired
parameters.name: callback

methods.value: add an event listener for the instance to receive view triggered events

methods.name: animate

parameters.description: either a dictionary of animation properties or an Animation object
parameters.name: obj

parameters.description: function to be invoked upon completion of the animation
parameters.name: callback

methods.value: animate the view

methods.name: fireEvent
methods.value: fire a synthesized event to the views listener

methods.name: hide
methods.value: hide the view

methods.name: pause
methods.value: pause a started animation.

methods.name: remove

parameters.description: the view to remove from this views hiearchy
parameters.name: view

methods.value: remove a previously add view from the view hiearchy

methods.name: removeEventListener
methods.value: remove a previously added event listener

methods.name: show
methods.value: make the view visible

methods.name: start
methods.value: start the image animation. this method only works if you set multiple images

methods.name: stop
methods.value: stop a started animation and reset the index to the first image

methods.name: toBlob
methods.value: return the image as a Blob object

methods.name: toImage

parameters.description: function to be invoked upon completion. if non-null, this method will be performed asynchronously. if null, it will be performed immediately
parameters.name: f

methods.value: return a Blob image of the rendered view

Titanium.UI.ImageView.notes: If you specify a width and/or height property on the image, the image will be scaled to fit into this space if the image is larger.

properties.name: anchorPoint
properties.value: a dictionary with properties x and y to indicate the anchor point value. anchor specifies the position by which animation should occur. center is 0.5, 0.5

properties.name: animatedCenterPoint
properties.value: read-only object with x and y properties of where the view is during animation

properties.name: animating
properties.value: readonly boolean to indicate if the animation is animating

properties.name: backgroundColor
properties.value: the background color of the view

properties.name: backgroundGradient
properties.value: a background gradient for the view with the properties: type,startPoint,endPoint,startRadius,endRadius,backfillStart,backfillEnd,colors.

properties.name: backgroundImage
properties.value: the background image url of the view

properties.name: backgroundLeftCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the left end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The right end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the left end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the width of the image

properties.name: backgroundTopCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the top end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The bottom end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the top end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the height of the image

properties.name: borderColor
properties.value: the border color of the view

properties.name: borderRadius
properties.value: the border radius of the view

properties.name: borderWidth
properties.value: the border width of the view

properties.name: bottom
properties.value: property for the view bottom position. this position is relative to the views parent. can be either a float value or a string of the width.

properties.name: canScale
properties.value: allow image to scale (Android)

properties.name: center
properties.value: a dictionary with properties x and y to indicate the center of the views position relative to the parent view

properties.name: defaultImage
properties.value: url to the default image to display while loading a remote image

properties.name: duration
properties.value: amount of time in milliseconds to animate one cycle

properties.name: enableZoomControls
properties.value: enable zoom controls on Android. Default is true for backward compatibility. (1.3.0)

properties.name: height
properties.value: height of the image display

properties.name: image
properties.value: image to display either as string url, Blob or File

properties.name: images
properties.value: array of images (either as string url, Blob or File) to display in an animation

properties.name: left
properties.value: property for the view left position. this position is relative to the views parent. can be either a float value or a string of the width.

properties.name: opacity
properties.value: the opacity from 0.0-1.0

properties.name: paused
properties.value: readonly boolean to indicate if the animation is paused

properties.name: preventDefaultImage
properties.value: boolean to indicate if the default image should be displaying while loading a remote image

properties.name: repeatCount
properties.value: number of times to repeat the image animation

properties.name: reverse
properties.value: boolean to indicate if the animation should happen in reverse (from last to first)

properties.name: right
properties.value: property for the view right position. this position is relative to the views parent. can be either a float value or a string of the width.

properties.name: size
properties.value: the size of the view as a dictionary of width and height properties

properties.name: top
properties.value: property for the view top position. this position is relative to the views parent. can be either a float value or a string of the width.

properties.name: touchEnabled
properties.value: a boolean indicating if the view should receive touch events (true, default) or forward them to peers (false)

properties.name: transform
properties.value: the transformation matrix to apply to the view

properties.name: url
properties.value: url to the image to display (NOTE: this property is deprecated. use image instead)

properties.name: visible
properties.value: a boolean of the visibility of the view

properties.name: width
properties.value: width of the image display

properties.name: zIndex
properties.value: the z index position relative to other sibling views

examples.code:
Create a label with a nice text shadow, 48px font that's aligned center and height auto.

var l2 = Titanium.UI.createLabel({
    text:'Appcelerator',
    height:'auto',
    width:'auto',
    shadowColor:'#aaa',
    shadowOffset:{x:5,y:5},
    color:'#900',
    font:{fontSize:48},
    textAlign:'center'
});

Titanium.UI.OptionDialog.description: The Option Dialog is created by Titanium.UI.createOptionDialog and allows you to show a modal dialog of one or more options to the user.

events.name: click

properties.cancel: boolean to indicate if the cancel button was pressed
properties.destructive: boolean to indicate if the destructive button was pressed
properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: fired when a button in the dialog is clicked

examples.code:
In this example, we show a simple option dialog.

var dialog = Titanium.UI.createOptionDialog({
    title: 'Hello',
    options: ['Option 1','Option 2'],
    cancel:1
});
dialog.show();

methods.name: show
methods.value: cause the dialog to become visible

properties.name: cancel
properties.value: an index to indicate which button should be the cancel button

properties.name: destructive
properties.value: the destructive button (indicated by a visual clue in the UI)

properties.name: options
properties.value: array of button names as strings

properties.name: title
properties.value: the title of the dialog

Titanium.UI.Picker.description: A Picker is created by the method Titanium.UI.createPicker. A Picker can be used to select one or more fixed values.

events.name: change

properties.source: the source object that fired the event
properties.type: the name of the event fired

events.value: fired when the value of a picker row and/or column changes

examples.code:
In this basic picker example, we create a one column picker with 4 rows. 

var picker = Titanium.UI.createPicker();
var data = [];
data[0]=Titanium.UI.createPickerRow({title:'Bananas'});
data[1]=Titanium.UI.createPickerRow({title:'Strawberries'});
data[2]=Titanium.UI.createPickerRow({title:'Mangos'});
data[3]=Titanium.UI.createPickerRow({title:'Grapes'});
picker.add(data);

In this example, we use a custom label for each row in a column.

var picker = Titanium.UI.createPicker();
var row = Titanium.UI.createPickerRow();
var label = Titanium.UI.createLabel({
    text:text,
    font:{fontSize:24,fontWeight:'bold'},
    color:text,
    width:'auto',
    height:'auto'
});
row.add(label);
picker.add(row);

methods.name: add

parameters.description: add an array of rows, a single row or a column to the picker
parameters.name: data

methods.value: add an array of rows, a single row or a column to the picker

methods.name: addEventListener

parameters.description: callback function to invoke when the event is fired
parameters.name: callback

methods.value: add an event listener for the instance to receive view triggered events

methods.name: fireEvent
methods.value: fire a synthesized event to the views listener

methods.name: getSelectedRow

parameters.description: for the column index, return the row object or nil if not found
parameters.name: index

methods.value: get the selected row object for column

methods.name: reloadColumn
methods.value: causes the picker to reload the values from the new column

methods.name: removeEventListener
methods.value: remove a previously added event listener

methods.name: setSelectedRow

parameters.description: boolean to indicate if the selection should be animated (default)
parameters.name: animated

methods.value: set the column's row to the selected state

Titanium.UI.Picker.notes: Android does not support the DateTime or Count Down Timer picker type.

properties.name: columns
properties.value: array of column values

properties.name: countDownDuration
properties.value: the duration value in milliseconds for count down timer pickers

properties.name: locale
properties.value: the locale used for displaying Date/Time pickers values

properties.name: maxDate
properties.value: the maximum Date/Time for value for date pickers

properties.name: minDate
properties.value: the minimum Date/Time for value for date pickers

properties.name: minuteInterval
properties.value: property to set the interval displayed by the minutes wheel (for example, 15 minutes). The interval value must be evenly divided into 60; if it is not, the default value is used. The default and minimum values are 1; the maximum value is 30.

properties.name: selectionIndicator
properties.value: for basic picker, boolean value to indicate whether the visual selection style is shown. On the iPhone, this is a blue selected bar.

properties.name: type
properties.value: the type constant for the picker. One of Titanium.UI.PICKER_TYPE_PLAIN (default), Titanium.UI.PICKER_TYPE_DATE_AND_TIME, Titanium.UI.PICKER_TYPE_DATE, Titanium.UI.PICKER_TYPE_TIME or Titanium.UI.PICKER_TYPE_COUNT_DOWN_TIMER.

properties.name: value
properties.value: the Date/Time value for date pickers

properties.name: anchorPoint
properties.value: a dictionary with properties x and y to indicate the anchor point value. anchor specifies the position by which animation should occur. center is 0.5, 0.5

properties.name: animatedCenterPoint
properties.value: read-only object with x and y properties of where the view is during animation

properties.name: backgroundColor
properties.value: the background color of the view

properties.name: backgroundGradient
properties.value: a background gradient for the view with the properties: type,startPoint,endPoint,startRadius,endRadius,backfillStart,backfillEnd,colors.

properties.name: backgroundImage
properties.value: the background image url of the view

properties.name: backgroundLeftCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the left end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The right end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the left end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the width of the image

properties.name: backgroundTopCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the top end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The bottom end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the top end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the height of the image

examples.code:
Since the row object is itself a view, you can add views and widgets to it to customize the the rows display. In the example below, we create a custom label for the row.

var row = Ti.UI.createPickerRow();
var label = Ti.UI.createLabel({
    text:text,
    font:{fontSize:24,fontWeight:'bold'},
    color:text,
    width:'auto',
    height:'auto'
});
row.add(label);
picker.add(row);
examples.description: Custom Views for a picker row

Titanium.UI.ProgressBar.description: A Progress Bar is created by the method Titanium.UI.createProgressBar.

examples.code:
In this example we create a progress bar with the min value of 0 and the max value of 10 and the current value of 0. The change the value of the progress bar to cause it to move, we would set the value property to a value between min and max.

var pb=Titanium.UI.createProgressBar({
    width:250,
    min:0,
    max:10,
    value:0,
    color:'#fff',
    message:'Downloading 0 of 10',
    font:{fontSize:14, fontWeight:'bold'},
    style:Titanium.UI.iPhone.ProgressBarStyle.PLAIN,
});

Titanium.UI.ProgressBar.notes: For iPhone, progress bar styles are constants defined in Titanium.UI.iPhone.ProgressBarStyle.

properties.name: color
properties.value: the color of the progress bar text

properties.name: font
properties.value: the font object for the progress bar text

properties.name: max
properties.value: the maximum value of the progress bar

properties.name: message
properties.value: the progress bar message

properties.name: min
properties.value: the minimum value of the progress bar

properties.name: style
properties.value: the style of the progress bar

properties.name: value
properties.value: the current value of the progress bar

Titanium.UI.ScrollView.description: A Scroll View is used to create a scrollable region of content. Views added to the Scroll View will be scrolled based on the content size of the Scroll View. The Scroll View is created by the method Titanium.UI.createScrollView. Note: In Android, Scroll Views can only scroll in one direction, either vertical or horizontal, but not both at the same time. See the Titanium.UI.ScrollView.scrollType property

examples.code:
Create a scroll view with content.

var scrollView = Titanium.UI.createScrollView({
    contentWidth:'auto',
    contentHeight:'auto',
    top:0,
    showVerticalScrollIndicator:true,
    showHorizontalScrollIndicator:true
});
var view = Ti.UI.createView({
    backgroundColor:'#336699',
    borderRadius:10,
    width:300,
    height:2000,
    top:10
});
scrollView.add(view);
Titanium.UI.currentWindow.add(scrollView);

Titanium.UI.ScrollableView.description: The Scrollable View provides a view that supports horizontal scrolling on one or more views in a gesture motion. The Scrollable View also optionally supports a visual paging control to indicate the page that the view is visible. The Scrollable View is created by the method Titanium.UI.createScrollableView.

examples.code:
Create three views and place each into a scrollable view.

var view1 = Titanium.UI.createView({backgroundColor:'#123'});
var view2 = Titanium.UI.createView({backgroundColor:'#123'});
var view3 = Titanium.UI.createView({backgroundColor:'#123'});
var scrollView = Titanium.UI.createScrollableView({
    views:[view1,view2,view3],
    showPagingControl:true
});
win.add(scrollView);

properties.name: anchorPoint
properties.value: a dictionary with properties x and y to indicate the anchor point value. anchor specifies the position by which animation should occur. center is 0.5, 0.5

properties.name: animatedCenterPoint
properties.value: read-only object with x and y properties of where the view is during animation

properties.name: backgroundColor
properties.value: the background color of the view

properties.name: backgroundGradient
properties.value: a background gradient for the view with the properties: type,startPoint,endPoint,startRadius,endRadius,backfillStart,backfillEnd,colors.

properties.name: backgroundImage
properties.value: the background image url of the view

properties.name: backgroundLeftCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the left end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The right end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the left end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the width of the image

properties.name: backgroundTopCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the top end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The bottom end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the top end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the height of the image

properties.value: the border color of the view

properties.name: borderRadius
properties.value: the border radius of the view

properties.name: borderWidth
properties.value: the border width of the view

examples.code:
The following is a simple example of a switch and receiving change events.

var basicSwitch = Titanium.UI.createSwitch({
    value:false
});
basicSwitch.addEventListener('change',function(e)
{
    Titanium.API.info('Basic Switch value = ' + e.value + ' act val ' + basicSwitch.value);
});

properties.name: anchorPoint
properties.value: a dictionary with properties x and y to indicate the anchor point value. anchor specifies the position by which animation should occur. center is 0.5, 0.5

properties.name: animatedCenterPoint
properties.value: read-only object with x and y properties of where the view is during animation

properties.name: backgroundColor
properties.value: the background color of the view

properties.name: backgroundGradient
properties.value: a background gradient for the view with the properties: type,startPoint,endPoint,startRadius,endRadius,backfillStart,backfillEnd,colors.

properties.name: backgroundImage
properties.value: the background image url of the view

properties.name: backgroundLeftCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the left end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The right end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the left end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the width of the image

properties.name: backgroundTopCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the top end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The bottom end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the top end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the height of the image

Titanium.UI.Tab.description: A TabGroup Tab instance. Each Tab instance maintains a stack of tab windows. Only one window within in the Tab can be visible at a time. When a window is closed, either by the user or by code, the window is removed from the stack, make the previous window visible. The root tab window cannot be removed. The Tab Group is created by the method Titanium.UI.createTab.

In this example, we create a simple tab and add it to a tab group.

var tab = Titanium.UI.createTab({
    window:mywin,
    title:'Hello',
    icon:'myicon.png'
});
tabGroup.addTab(tab);

properties.value: read-only object with x and y properties of where the view is during animation

properties.name: backgroundColor
properties.value: the background color of the view

properties.name: backgroundGradient
properties.value: a background gradient for the view with the properties: type,startPoint,endPoint,startRadius,endRadius,backfillStart,backfillEnd,colors.

properties.name: backgroundImage
properties.value: the background image url of the view

properties.name: backgroundLeftCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the left end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The right end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the left end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the width of the image

properties.name: backgroundTopCap
properties.value: End caps specify the portion of an image that should not be resized when an image is stretched. This technique is used to implement buttons and other resizable image-based interface elements. When a button with end caps is resized, the resizing occurs only in the middle of the button, in the region between the end caps. The end caps themselves keep their original size and appearance. This property specifies the size of the top end cap. The middle (stretchable) portion is assumed to be 1 pixel wide. The bottom end cap is therefore computed by adding the size of the top end cap and the middle portion together and then subtracting that value from the height of the image

Titanium.UI.TabbedBar.description: A Tabbed Bar is created by the method Titanium.UI.createTabbedBar. The difference between the Tabbed Bar and the Button Bar is that the tabbed bar visually maintains a state (visually distinguished as a pressed or selected look).

var data = [{title:"Row 1"},{title:"Row 2"}];
var table = Titanium.UI.createTableView({data:data});
win.add(table);

var row = Titanium.UI.createTableViewRow();
var view = Titanium.UI.createView({backgroundColor:'red',width:20,height:20});
row.height = 'auto';
row.add(view);
